title: 114_hr2471
content: The "Maximizing America's Prosperity Act of 2015" establishes total spending limits under Section 251 of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. The "Maximizing America's Prosperity Act of 2015" requires reports comparing projected total spending under section 257 with spending limits, to be included in the budget and CBO reports. Within 15 days after Congress adjourns, a spending reduction order must be issued. The "Maximizing America's Prosperity Act of 2015" mandates automatic spending reductions for non-exempt discretionary budget accounts based on a percentage of GDP for fiscal years 2016 to 2021, with a maximum reduction of five percent. The "Maximizing America's Prosperity Act of 2015" sets automatic spending reductions based on a percentage of GDP for fiscal years 2021 to 2025. The reductions are specified for each fiscal year and include a reduction for unfunded federal mandates. Section 251A of the Balanced Budget Act is repealed. The "Maximizing America's Prosperity Act of 2015" repeals Section 251A of the Balanced Budget Act and introduces new definitions related to total spending, total spending limit, and potential GDP. The "Maximizing America's Prosperity Act of 2015" repeals certain sections of the Balanced Budget Act, including definitions related to spending limits and potential GDP. Amendments are made to various sections of the Act to remove references to sequestration and adjust language regarding spending reduction. The "Maximizing America's Prosperity Act of 2015" amends sections of the Balanced Budget Act to remove references to sequestration and adjust language regarding spending reduction. The "Maximizing America's Prosperity Act of 2015" amends sections of the Balanced Budget Act to remove references to sequestration and adjust language regarding spending reduction, including a conforming amendment to Section 250. The "Maximizing America's Prosperity Act of 2015" amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to allocate 1 percent of new budget authority for emergencies to the Committees on Appropriations. This emergency spending provision is also reflected in the United States Code.
